Violation_Type: Excessive demand on health or social services
Legal_Issue: Did the medical officers err in determining excessive demand on health or social services under s. 19(1)(a)(ii) of the Immigration Act?
Application_Facts: Medical narrative focused primarily on educational expenses without considering family support or service availability.
Court_Ruling: Decision set aside and remanded to a different visa officer for rehearing
Defendant_Behavior: Medical officers failed to obtain necessary information
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable application of statutory test due to incomplete assessment
Legal_Standard: Excessive demand on health or social services under s. 19(1)(a)(ii)
Assessment_Factor: Educational and social service costs, family support, service availability
Procedural_Issue: Failure to obtain necessary information; lack of procedural fairness
Application_Basis: Potential excessive demand on health or social services
Evidence_Assessed: Focus on educational expenses without holistic evaluation
Governing_Rule: A person is inadmissible if their admission would cause excessive demands on health or social services
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider relevant factors such as family support and service availability
Harm_Assessment: Risk of unjustified denial of entry based on incomplete medical assessment
Cause_Description: Applicant's daughter deemed medically inadmissible based on potential excessive demands on services
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient collection and analysis of supporting information
Evidence_Issues: Incomplete medical opinion, narrow focus on education costs
Evidence_Assessment: Defective due to failure to obtain necessary information
Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable application of statutory test due to inadequate factual basis
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of comprehensive data on service demands and supports
Legal_Standard_Applied: Excessive demand on health or social services
